Styling lexical entries with CSS
Basic use Use the class selector and add some styles. You can find an excellent tutorial here: http://www.w3schools.com/css/ Example Say you have added a decorator to your view. To that decorator you added your 'lexeme' data category by dragging it there from the Lexicon structure panel. In the class field for the decorator you entered 'lexeme'. To make your 'lexeme' class use a 20pt Times Roman red font, do this: .lexeme { font-family: Lucida Sans Unicode; font-size: 20pt; color: red; } Your lexeme will look like this ઓે્િસલકત Note that a class selector is a dot '.' followed by the class name followed by '{' and '}'. You add your styles between the '{' and '}' characters.
Style the entire lexical entry If you want to modify the style for the whole lexical entry modify the body selector. For example to add a purple background use this: body { background-color:#7722EE; } (Note there is no dot '.' in front of the body selector.)
Font font-family: Lucida Sans Unicode; font-size: 20pt;
Background color background-color:#b0c4de;
Text color:#b0c4de; color: red; text-align:center; text-decoration:underline; text-transform:uppercase; text-transform:capitalize; text-indent:5pt;
Tables border: 1px solid black; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%; height:50px; text-align:right; vertical-align:bottom;
Margins & Padding margin-top:100px; margin-bottom:100px; margin-right:50px; margin-left:50px; padding-top:25px; padding-bottom:25px; padding-right:50px; padding-left:50px;
Block vs inline CSS is based on the box model, i.e. everything is in a box. By default every box repels other boxes, e.g. everything is 'on a line by itself'. You can change this by using the CSS feature display. display: block; display: inline;
Powerful CSS is very powerful, allowing you to do very exact styling. It is impossible to provide a complete reference here, but the styles above are used most often. See http://www.w3schools.com/css/ for a friendly and complete reference on CSS.
